title: How to Dry Pasta

steps.headline: Spread parchment paper and flour over a small baking sheet.
steps.description: Cut a piece of parchment paper to the size of your baking sheet. Line the paper over your baking sheet and press it tightly around the perimeter. Sprinkle a small amount of flour over the top until there is a light coating across the surface of the sheet. For larger batches of pasta, repeat this process for additional baking sheets until you have enough space. Keep your baking sheets small for drying pasta clumps so that they can all fit into the stream of the small fan.

steps.headline: Place your fresh shaped pasta mounds onto the parchment paper.
steps.description: Gently roll your shaped traditional noodles into small mounds about 4 to 5 inches (10 to 13 cm) across. Place each mound of noodles onto the parchment paper. Allow about 1 inch (2.5 cm) between them so they don't stick together. Sprinkle a light layer of flour over the pasta after placing them on the paper. Don't fill each piece of parchment paper with more than 1 layer of pasta mounds.

steps.headline: Set up a small fan in front of the pasta for 5 minutes to decrease drying time.
steps.description: Clumps of pasta take longer to dry, so beginning with a quick fan dry is ideal. Place the baking sheet on a flat surface like a table that is near an outlet. Face the fan in front of your pasta about 1 foot (0.30 m) from the pan and turn it on. After 5 minutes, turn the fan off. Be sure that your pan is small enough that the fan can expose all of the pasta to cool air.

steps.headline: Leave the pasta clumps uncovered for 12 to 24 hours until they're dry.
steps.description: After turning off the fan, let the pasta dry at room temperature. Touch the pasta clumps every now and then to see if they bend—this is a sign they need more time to dry. Gently twist a piece of pasta after 12 to 24 hours—if it breaks, it's dry. Store your pasta clumps in airtight containers and put them in the refrigerator for up to 2 days or the freezer for up to 2 weeks.

steps.headline: Cover a large baking sheet with parchment paper and flour.
steps.description: Cut a piece of parchment paper to approximately the size of a large baking sheet. Flatten it over the sheet with your hands and firmly press it along the edges. Afterward, sprinkle a thin layer of flour over the sheet. Be sure your baking sheet has a long enough width for the length of your pasta and remember that each one can only accommodate a single layer of pasta. Repeat this process for additional baking sheets as necessary. If you don't have enough baking sheets, you can use hangers or pasta racks for any sheets or strings that don't fit onto the sheets.

steps.headline: Line your noodles vertically onto the baking sheet.
steps.description: Gently place each noodle onto the sheet parallel with the width of the pan. Try to ensure that the pieces don't touch each other as much as you can. Be careful not to overhandle the noodles as you spread them to dry—they can break apart. Sprinkle some flour over your noodles once they are laid out. Set aside extra noodles onto loose parchment paper to hang afterwards.

steps.headline: Place small 2 by 1 foot (0.61 by 0.30 m) parchment paper pieces over hangers.
steps.description: Find a hanger and estimate the size of parchment paper that can fold over it—a 2 by 1 foot (0.61 by 0.30 m) piece should be fine for most hangers. Fold the piece over the hanger so that each of its halves hang over opposing sides. Determine how many hangers you need to hold all of the excess pasta and cut a piece of paper for each one.

steps.headline: Hang your excess pasta to dry on the hangers.
steps.description: Gently place each piece of pasta over the paper. Give each piece of pasta about 0.25 to 0.5 inches (0.64 to 1.27 cm) of space between the other. For lasagna pieces, they can be closer together. Store your hangers around the kitchen on knobs. You can also place a broom handle horizontally over a couple of chairs and hang your pasta from it.

steps.headline: Wait 12 to 24 hours for the pieces of pasta to dry.
steps.description: Regularly check on the pasta pieces by gently bending them at the tip to determine their hardness. If you can break the pasta pieces by bending them, they are sufficiently dry. Remember that humidity, temperature, and noodle size can affect drying time.

steps.headline: Line a large baking sheet with parchment paper and flour.
steps.description: Cut a piece of parchment paper to the size of your baking sheet. Press it firmly onto the sheet and sprinkle a light layer of flour over the top of the paper. Be sure that each baking sheet only contains a single layer of pasta. If you have a large batch of fresh pasta, line additional baking sheets until you have enough space.

steps.headline: Spread your small pasta pieces over the sheet in a single layer.
steps.description: Try to ensure that the pieces aren't touching as much as you can. Once they are all lined up, sprinkle a small amount of flour on top of them to prevent them from sticking together. Layer small batches of pasta onto loose parchment paper to save space or if you don't have enough baking sheets. Small pasta pieces include bowties, penne, and fusilli.

steps.headline: Leave the pasta uncovered for 12 to 24 hours or until it's completely dry.
steps.description: Gently stir the pasta and turn each piece over 2 to 3 times during this period. Keep an eye on the moisture of your pasta—drying time can vary with temperature, humidity, and noodle size. To test your pasta for dryness, twist a piece—it should snap, not bend.
